bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to John Goodwin, 1708 September 25

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant John Goodwin, September 25, 1708, that the sons of Ralph Wormeley have assumed management of their own affairs, and thus, he will not write again about the estate. He adds that he has drawn a bill of exchange on Goodwin to Doctor John Lomax to pay a debt of the estate.

div1.head: Robert Carter to John Goodwin, September 25, 1708
div1.opener:
[Rappahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]>
[September 25, 1708]
Mr. Jno Goodwin
div1.p:
The Young Wormeleys are now Supravisors of their own Estate I ha[ve told]
them nor will You further hear from me on their Accot only have now [to tell]
You I have drawn on You for 4£ 10p to Doctor [John] Lomax being a debt due from [the estate]
& You are to pay it accordingly Charging it to the Debit thereof

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Christ Church Parish, Lancaster County, Processioners' Returns, 1711-1783,and Wormeley Estate Papers, 1701-1710, 1716, Acc. 30126, Archives Research Services, Library of Virginia, Richmond, 179.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The return address, county, and state have been added for clarity to this unheaded letter.
[1] This letter precedes another of this date in the letter book on the same theme.
